oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Andrew Jackson and troops departing for New Orleans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color engraving, "Dearture of the Troops for New Orleans," shows Andrew Jackson and his mounted troops departing on horseback for New Orleans. Jackson, atop his white horse, speaks to an officer. Black and white version also in folder. From John Frost and W. Croome, "Pictorial Life of Ander Jackson." Possibly engraved by Devereux.

Kentuckians and Tennesseans comprised most of Jackson's militia. The Americans overwhelmed the British at the Battle of New Orleans on January 8, 1815. Because of slow transatlantic communication, neither side knew that the Treaty of Ghent had been signed two weeks earlier. Consequently, the battle had no effect on the war's outcome. Jackson came into national prominence and was elected 7th President in 1828. He was reelected in 1832.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Horses; Generals
